facts.text: Writ Petition No. 76 of 1957 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 76 of 1957. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights. S. Pathak, J. B. Dadachanji, R

facts.text: Judgment delivered on August 30, 1962 by SHAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. August 30. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-The petitioners profess the Christian faith and belong to the United Church of Northern India.

facts.text: Petitioners profess the Christian faith and belong to the United Church of Northern India.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-The petitioners profess the Christian faith and belong to the United Church of Northern India. They are members of the Gujarat and Kathiawar Presbyterian Joint Board-hereinafter called the society-

facts.text: Petitioners are members of the Gujarat and Kathiawar Presbyterian Joint Board (society).

anchor.surface_text: They are members of the Gujarat and Kathiawar Presbyterian Joint Board-hereinafter called the society-which companyducts in the areas which number form the State of Gujarat,forty two primary schools and a Training College for teachers, known as the Mary Brown Memorial Training College. at Borsad, District Kaira.

facts.text: Society conducts forty two primary schools and Mary Brown Memorial Training College at Borsad, District Kaira.

anchor.surface_text: which companyducts in the areas which number form the State of Gujarat,forty two primary schools and a Training College for teachers, known as the Mary Brown Memorial Training College. at Borsad, District Kaira. The teachers trained in the companyleges are absorbed in the primary schools companyducted by the, society and those number so absorbed are employed by other Christian Mission Schools companyducted by the United Church of Northern India.

facts.text: Cost of maintaining Training College and primary schools met out of donations from Irish Presbyterian Mission, fees from scholars, and grant-in-aid under Education Code.

anchor.surface_text: The companyt of maintaining the Training companylege and the primary schools is met out of donations received from the Irish Presbyterian Mission, fee from scholars and grant-in-aid under the education Code of the State Government.

facts.text: Primary schools and college conducted for benefit of religious denomination of United Church of Northern India and Indian Christians generally, though admission not denied to other communities.

anchor.surface_text: The primary schools and the companylege are companyducted for the benefit of the religious denomination of the United Church  if Northern India and Indian Christians generally, though admission is number denied to students belonging to other companymunities.

facts.text: Training course in college is of two years duration, originally 25 students First Year and 25 Second Year.

anchor.surface_text: The training companyrse in the companylege is of the duration of two years and originally 25 students were admitted in the First Year and 25 in the Second Year.

facts.text: Till 1952, surplus accommodation available after admitting students for society's primary schools.

anchor.surface_text: Till the year 1952 surplus accommodation after admitting students who were to qualify as teachers required for the societys primary schools, was available for other students

facts.text: College recognised by Government of Bombay for training students for examination for certificates for trained teachers.

anchor.surface_text: The College was recognised by the Government of Bombay for training students for the examination held by the Education Department for granting certificates for trained teachers.

facts.text: In November 1952, Government of Bombay ordered all private Training Colleges to reserve 60% seats for School Boards teachers nominated by Government.

anchor.surface_text: In November 1952 the Government of Bombay ordered all private Training Colleges in the State to reserve 60 of seats for training Boards School teachers numberinated by the Government.

facts.text: Society protested against November 1952 order; negotiations led to agreement to admit 20 students every year, 10 in each class.

anchor.surface_text: he society protested against the order. There, were negotiations between the Education Department of the Government and the society and it was agreed that the society should admit every year 20 students, 10 in each class.

facts.text: In June 1953, 10 students nominated by Government admitted.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, in June 1953, 10 students were numberinated by the Government and another batch of ten students was numberinated in June, 1954.

facts.text: In June 1954, another 10 students nominated by Government admitted.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, in June 1953, 10 students were numberinated by the Government and another batch of ten students was numberinated in June, 1954.

facts.text: On May 28, 1955, Government of Bombay issued order for 80% seats reserved in non-Government Training Colleges from academic year 1955-56.

anchor.surface_text: On May 28, 1955, the Government of Bombay issued another order that with effect from the academic year 1955-56, 80 of the seats should be reserved by the Management in number-Government Training Colleges for the District and Municipal School Board teachers to be numberinated by the Government.

facts.text: Order of May 28, 1955 recited 40,000 untrained primary teachers employed by District School Boards and Municipalities.

anchor.surface_text: It was recited in the order that there were 40,000 untrained primary teachers employed by District School Boards and Authorised Municipalities,and some more untrained teachers were likely to be selected and appointed as primary teachers during the next academic year

facts.text: On June 13, 1955, Educational Inspector Kaira District informed Principal to reserve 80% seats for School Board teachers, not admit private students exceeding 20% without permission.

anchor.surface_text: On June 13, 1955, the Educational Inspector, Kaira District addressed a letter to the Principal of the College informing him that 80 of the total number of seats in the training companylege be reserved for school Board teachers ,deputed by the Government,

facts.text: On June 15, 1955, Principal expressed inability to comply with June 13 order.

anchor.surface_text: The Principal of the College, by letter dated June 15, 1955, expressed his inability to companyply with the order.

facts.text: On December 27, 1955, Educational Inspector warned society for refusing admission, threatened no grant unless reserve 80% from 1956-57, limit classes, else withdraw recognition.

anchor.surface_text: By letter dated December 27, 1955, the Educational Inspector, Kaira District informed the management of the College that the action taken by them in refusing admission to the School Board teachers was highly irregular and against the Government policy,

facts.text: On February 10, 1956, society submitted memorial to Minister for Education protesting threats.

anchor.surface_text: The society submitted on February 10, 1956 a memorial to the Minister for Education Government of Bombay protesting against the threat to take disciplinary action and to withdraw recognition.

facts.text: On March 12, 1956, society informed grant for current year withheld.

anchor.surface_text: By letter dated March 12,1956, the society was informed that in view of the refusal of the society to reserve seats for the school Board teachers, grant for the current year was withheld.

facts.text: On March 22, 1956, society requested permission to fill 12 places each year, reserve remaining 60%.

anchor.surface_text: By letter dated March 22, 1956, the society wrote to the Minister for Education requesting that they be permitted to fill twelve places in each year and the remaining places  which amounted to 60 of the total strength  be reserved for School Board teachers.

facts.text: Government makes annual grant of Rs. 8,000/- to the college under Education Code.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the Government of Bombay makes under the Education Code a grant of Rs. 8,000/- annually to the companylege.

facts.text: College is non-profit making, depends on donations and government grant.

anchor.surface_text: The College is a number-profit making institution and depends primarily upon donations and Government grant for meeting its expenses.

facts.text: Dr. D.V. Chickermane affidavit states over 8,900 primary schools, about 40,000 untrained teachers.

anchor.surface_text: In support of his argument, reliance is placed upon the affidavit of Dr. D.V. Chickermane who affirmed that the number of Primary and Basic Schools in the State run by District School or Municipal Boards and others was great, primary schools alone being over 8,900 and the untrained personnel in all the primary schools was about 40,000

facts.text: Truth of Dr. Chickermane's statements not denied by petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: The truth of these statements made in Dr. Chickermanes affidavit is number denied by the petitioners.

concepts.interpretation: Prohibits discrimination in aid on ground of minority management; does not permit substantive restrictions on administration.

holdings.text: Interference with the right of bare management of an educational institution does not amount to infringement of the right to property under Art. 19(1)(f). The petitioners have no proprietary rights like a Mathadhipati.

anchor.surface_text: Interference with the right of bare management of an educational institution does number amount to infringement of the right to property under Art.  1   f . Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shiru Mutt  1  on which reliance is placed by the Society does number lay down any proposition to the  1  1954 S.C. R. 1005 companytrary.

precedents.citation: The Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shiru Mutt [1954] S.C.R. 1005

anchor.surface_text: The decision of this Court in The Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shiru Mutt  1  on which reliance is placed by the Society does number lay down any proposition to the  1  1954 S.C. R. 1005 companytrary. The Court was dealing in that case with the alleged infringement of the rights of a Mahant in a religious institution by the, enactment of the Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, XIX of 1951.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt
precedents.cited_proposition: Mathadhipati has proprietary interest blending office and property protected under Art. 19(1)(f)
precedents.cited_holding: Thus in the conception of Mahantship, as in Shebaitship, both the elements of office and property, of duties and personal interest are blended-together and neither can be detached from the other.

precedents.citation: Sri Dwarka Nath Tewari v. State of Bihar A.I.R. 1959 S.C. 249

anchor.surface_text: Nor does the principle of Sri Dwarka Nath Tewari v. State of Bihar  1  apply to this case. In Dwarka Naths case, by an executive order the Government of Bihar purported to divest the trustees of a school of their right to land and building belonging to the school. The Court held that the applicants in whom the land and the building of the school were vested as the Managing Committee of the school companyld number be divested of A. I. R.  1959  S.C. 249.

precedents.case_name: Dwarka Nath Tewari v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: Government cannot divest trustees of school property by executive order
precedents.cited_holding: the applicants in whom the land and the building of the school were vested as the Managing Committee of the school could not be divested of their rights by the mere fiat of an official of the Government.
